etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in William Shakespeare (1564–1616), playwright and poet. From Spanish malhecho wrongful act from mal bad + hecho deed, use as noun of past participle of hacer to do from classical Latin facere

definitions: Probably: wrongdoing, misdeeds. In later use in allusion to Shakespeare's miching malicho and taken to be generally suggestive of dark deeds, mystery, or intrigue, and used in these senses.

notes.text: Malone (1790) glosses as: a secret and wicked contrivance; a concealed wickedness.
